newsitem.title: ISRAEL: Israeli convicted of spitting in front of cross.
newsitem.headline: Israeli convicted of spitting in front of cross.

text.p: An Israeli court begged to differ this week with a man who claimed spitting before a cross or church was common Jewish practice and should not be viewed as violating laws defending religious worship.
Courts spokesman Moshe Gorali confirmed the details of the case published in Israel's Haaretz daily on Friday.
Haaretz quoted defendant Moshe Arenfeld's lawyer as saying: "Freedom of expression allows a person the freedom to spit...in the presence of religious clergy carrying a cross."
He continued: "One cannot ignore the common practice in Judaism that a Jew must spit when he passes a church or encounters a cross."

The defence did the man no good and his appeal against the conviction for spitting on the ground when a procession of priests carrying a cross passed him in Jerusalem was rejected by the court which fined him $250.
The court said Israel's concentration of diverse religious communities in a small area created a sensitive situation where it was necessary to protect religious practices.
